newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Portugal denies it imported gene-modified maize.
newsitem.headline: Portugal denies it imported gene-modified maize.

text.p: A government spokesman denied on Monday that Portugal had imported U.S. gene-modified maize in breach of EU rules.
"Portugal has not imported any U.S. gene-modified maize. We are awaiting the decision of the European Commission," Augusto Vilela of the Agriculture Ministry told Reuters.
A European Union diplomat told reporters in Brussels on Friday that shipments of U.S. gene-modified maize may already have arrived in Portugal and Spain in breach of EU rules.
The diplomat was referring to cargoes containing corn from this year's U.S. harvest, the first to include a gene-modified strain made by Swiss chemicals company Ciba-Geigy AG.

The European Commission is due to decide on December 18 whether to allow imports of the modified maize, which Ciba-Geigy has altered to make it resistant to the corn borer pest and to increase its tolerance of certain weedkillers.
A Commission decision to clear the maize, which U.S. authorities have approved, will depend on advice from EU committees on food, animal feed and pesticides.
